evidence_span: The mechanical properties of the final tubes depend on the final heat treatment and slightly on the first steps of the fabrication sequence, leading to small differences in the grain size.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: The nodular corrosion sensitivity of the recrystallized cladding tubes points out the influence of the early fabrication steps: The increase of the alpha annealing temperature in any fabrication step is detrimental.

evidence_span: Among the tubes tested in this program those with the best nodular corrosion resistance in the high-pressure steam test had the worst behavior using ASTM Practice for Aqueous Corrosion Testing of Samples of Zirconium and Zirconium Alloys (G 2).

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_034_chunk5

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: It was found that a high cooling rate from the beta or alpha-plus-beta range is the best way to achieve products with good nodular corrosion resistance in a high-pressure steam test
process_step: cooling from beta or alpha-plus-beta range

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: subsequent hot working, and alpha annealing after cold rolling, led to a decrease in the nodular corrosion resistance
process_step: hot working, alpha annealing after cold rolling

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_034_chunk5
evidence_span: To obtain the best nodular corrosion resistance, the final product should be quenched from the beta (or alpha-plus-beta) range, but these structures may be detrimental for the other properties.
process_step: quenching from beta or alpha-plus-beta range
